extractions.description: The paper discusses innovative approaches in improving the scalability and performance of non-parametric Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). The authors introduce a novel module, non-parametric attention (NPA), aimed at overcoming the over-smoothing issues and fixed-weight limitations of existing non-parametric models. The effectiveness of NPA is validated through extensive experiments on homophilic and heterophilic graphs, showing significant performance improvements.

type.justification: The paper involves experimental results on six homophilic graphs and five heterophilic graphs to validate their approach, which qualifies it as an empirical study.
type.quote: Experimental results on six homophilic graphs and five heterophilic graphs demonstrate NPA enjoys high performance – achieves large performance gain over existing non-parametric GNNs

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on improving non-parametric Graph Neural Networks (GNNs).
name.quote: Recent works show great interest in designing Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) that scale to large graphs.

name.justification: The paper proposes methods specifically aimed to enhance the scalability of non-parametric GNNs.
name.quote: we present non-parametric attention (NPA), a plug-and-play module that is compatible with non-parametric GNNs, to get scalable and deep GNNs simultaneously.

name.justification: The experiments were conducted on semi-supervised node classification tasks.
name.quote: We test the effectiveness of NPA in the widely used semi-supervised node classification task, and the goal is to predict the labels for nodes in the unlabeled set Vu with the supervision of labeled set Vl.

name.justification: NPA (non-parametric attention) is introduced as a novel module in the paper.
name.quote: we present non-parametric attention (NPA), a plug-and-play module that is compatible with non-parametric GNNs

is_contributed.justification: The paper specifically introduces this model as a new contribution.
is_contributed.quote: we present non-parametric attention (NPA), a plug-and-play module that is compatible with non-parametric GNNs

is_executed.justification: Experimental results demonstrate the execution of NPA on various datasets, hence it was executed in practice.
is_executed.quote: Experimental results on six homophilic graphs and five heterophilic graphs demonstrate NPA enjoys high performance

is_compared.justification: NPA is compared against other non-parametric GNN models in terms of performance and scalability.
is_compared.quote: Experimental results on six homophilic graphs and five heterophilic graphs demonstrate NPA enjoys high performance – achieves large performance gain over existing non-parametric GNNs

referenced_paper_title.justification: As a novel contribution, NPA does not reference a previous paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we present non-parametric attention (NPA), a plug-and-play module that is compatible with non-parametric GNNs

name.justification: Explicitly mentioned in the paper and used in the experiments.
name.quote: Notably, it achieves state-of-the-art performance on the large ogbn-papers100M dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Open Graph Benchmark: Datasets for Machine Learning on Graphs
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is part of the Open Graph Benchmark, as cited in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: most top solutions in Open Graph Benchmark (Hu et al., 2020) are non-parametric GNNs

name.justification: Explicitly mentioned in the paper and used in the experiments.
name.quote: Specifically, we plug it into five typical non-parametric GNNs and conduct extensive experiments on real-world datasets. ogbn-arxiv

name.justification: Explicitly mentioned in the paper and used in the experiments.
name.quote: we conduct node classification tasks on six homophilic graph datasets. Table 1 shows the test accuracy of the baselines with and without the proposed NPA module. Experimental results show that the proposed NPA consistently helps all baseline methods achieve better predictive performance on three citation datasets. Citation datasets Cora

referenced_paper_title.value: Semi-Supervised Classification with Graph Convolutional Networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is historically referenced to this paper by Kipf and Welling, 2017.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we conduct node classification tasks on six homophilic graph datasets. Table 1 shows the test accuracy of the baselines with and without the proposed NPA module. Experimental results show that the proposed NPA consistently helps all baseline methods achieve better predictive performance on three citation datasets. Citation datasets Cora
